none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. E. Edmond, July 18, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. E. Edmond, July 18, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 20 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Kingsbury. Texas
18 July 1885

Prof L L McInnis-

Sir

I am very much obliged for
your sending me Catalogue
of your College. When I wrote
the Honl Mr Pfeuffer I was
under the impression yours was
a State aided school and
that farmers like myself could
for a moderate sum get their
boys a good education but
my surprise was great to find
your terms were higher than
the first Class English or
Irish Schools where when
at home I could no more

**Summary of Transcription Process**

Okay, here's how I approached this. The goal was to take a handwritten letter and produce a digital transcription, carefully considering every detail. First, I meticulously *analyzed the image*: identified it as a letter dated July 18, 1885, from Kingsbury, Texas, addressed to a Professor L.L. McInnis. The content was a thank-you note but also a bit of a complaint about the school's high tuition, especially since it was implied it was a "state-aided school". The sender compared the cost to English and Irish schools. The handwriting was generally legible, though cursive, so I made sure to identify all the words and phrases. I got a little stuck on the month of the date – it could have been "July" or maybe "August" or even "January", but after a closer look, it was clearly "July".

Next, I jumped into *formatting*. I understood I needed to use HTML tags – specifically `p`, `br`, `span`, etc. – and that line breaks were crucial. The aim was to retain the original look of the letter on the page.

Then came the *specific word checks*. This is where the real deep dive began. "Kingsbury. Texas" was straightforward. "18 July 1885" needed care, particularly the "J" in July. "Prof L L McInnis" was clean. "Honl" was definitely the abbreviation for "Honorable", and I noted the superscript ‘l’. "Mr" also had the superscript ‘r’. The name "Pfeuffer" felt important, so I cross-referenced it with historical figures and found a George Pfeuffer associated with Texas A&M, making the context of a state-aided school more probable. The ink blot near "my surprise was great" gave me pause – it looked like a correction, either the writer had started to write "is" or "it was" before deciding on "was." After close consideration of the structure of the sentence, I transcribed it as "was". Also, I looked really close and I think it says "It was" written over, then crossed out. I opted to write what seemed to be the clear final intent. The details such as capitalization ("State aided", "English", "Irish") needed close attention.

The *reading order and layout* guided me in how I’d structure the transcription. Header aligned right, salutation left, and body text formatted.

I then did a *draft transcription*, just getting all the words down.

That brought me to *refinement*. This is where I worried about the precise use of HTML. I chose to handle the superscript abbreviation mark. Since the guidelines only allowed `sub` and `sup`, I figured this was the right choice. "Honl" would now be "Hon<sup>l</sup>". "M<sup>r</sup>" also got the `sup` treatment. I re-evaluated "sum", "moderate" and the confusing "was". I ensured capital letters where required.

Finally, I did a *final polish*, cross-checking my transcription against the original line breaks, making absolutely sure the text was accurate and complete. I made some fine-tuned decisions based on my historical knowledge and grammatical sense. I also made sure to follow formatting instructions to ensure that the layout closely matched the intent of the author.

This process was a deep dive into historical document analysis. I tried to render the letter with the most fidelity possible while maintaining readability.

than to your institution afford
to send my three sons - I can
in the fall send my boy
home to Ireland nearly 7000
miles, pay his fare and one
year at School and as
good a one as yours Could
possibly be all for not
more than one half what
it would cost me at Bryan
If this is state aid to Education
what must it be to send
a boy to a non. endowed
School? I Could have my
boy educated in Trinity
College Dublin boarding out
for a sum not more than
you charge, and a Trinity
degree is a passport all
over the world - I will now

**Summary of My Transcription Process**

Okay, here's what I've been thinking through as I tackle this transcription.  First, I'm carefully analyzing the image. It's a handwritten letter on lined paper, the handwriting is cursive, it's a bit hurried, and generally legible, but there are some ink blots – particularly near the bottom. The text suggests that this is a continuation from a previous page, which could provide context, but I don't have that context in front of me. I'm going to proceed line by line.

I'm starting at the top: the first line, "than to your institution afford." The handwriting is pretty clear overall, I'm interpreting this, and it looks like "intitution," but I'm inferring it as "institution" as it makes more sense with the words around it, and it's likely a cursive shorthand. The context suggests that the sentence construction is a comparison, so I'm putting it that way. The next line, "to send my three sons – I can," is straightforward, the "three" is written clearly.

As I'm moving down to the line "in the fall send my boy," that's pretty clear as well. And I keep progressing. When I hit the word "Ireland," I'm making sure to capitalize it. When I hit the number 7000 I'm confirming that this is correct. In line 6, the word "School" I'm capitalizing. On line 7, I'm capitalizing the word "Could," as it's the start of the clause.

I hit an interesting point in line 10. The word "Bryan," most likely, is the name of a place or school. Given the context of "state aid," the place in Texas makes perfect sense, but it may be another name or just a random place.

Next, on line 11, the word "Educatio" is truncated, so I'm making the editorial decision to write "Education."

On line 13, it seems to say "non.endowed" or "non endowed." There is a dot, so I'm preserving the dot.

On line 14, there is a word "School!", there is a mark in the handwriting, looks like an exclamation or question mark. "If this is state aid... what must it be... non endowed School?", so I'll render the mark as a question mark, as the grammar implies a question.

In line 16, "Dublin", there's also a mark after the word, and I'll preserve it.

Line 17 has the ink blot. I'm inferring the obscured word, so I'll write "not."

I'm keeping my HTML tagging and line breaks, and making sure the final transcription looks as it would on the page.

I've also gone through a number of double checks: to ensure that the words are written correctly and that my inferences and decisions were correct.

My final output is formatted. And that's about it.

send my boy to our Irish Masonic School where
I can keep him well for one hundred dollars
a year - You will excuse me writing thus
plain but I do it with every respect for
yourself and your College.

Yr
obdt
J.E. Edmond

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter** Alright, let's break this down. First, I need to transcribe this image of a handwritten letter, paying close attention to the orientation—it's rotated 90 degrees clockwise—and make sure I read it naturally. The text is on lined paper, so preserving the line breaks is essential. I'm seeing a clear request: "send my boy to our Irish Masonic School where I can keep him well for one hundred dollars a year - You will excuse me writing thus plain but I do it with every respect for yourself and your College." Standard stuff, clearly a formal request. The closing is where I need to be extra meticulous. "Yr obdt servt"—or is it? The image isn’t perfectly clear. Looking very closely, I'm thinking the text reads "Yr obdt", followed by a signature: "J.E. Edmond". The "Yr obdt" is the crux of the issue. The handwriting is a bit scrawled, so the closing requires careful scrutiny. It’s likely "Yr obdt" which is a common abbreviation for "Your obedient". There's no "servt" following, it's just "Yr obdt" with the signature below. So, let's transcribe. I'll use `

` for the body and `
` for the line breaks to preserve the visual formatting of the handwritten letter. Here's the final output:

send my boy to our Irish Masonic School where
I can keep him well for one hundred dollars
a year - You will excuse me writing thus
plain but I do it with every respect for
yourself and your College.

Yr obdt
J.E. Edmond
